claim: The area of a rectangle is length × width

supporting.text: The formula for the area of a rectangle is derived from the basic principle of multiplying the number of unit squares that fit along its length by the number that fit along its width.

attacks.text: The formula for the area of a rectangle is derived from the basic principle of multiplying the number of unit squares that fit along its length by the number that fit along its width.
The formula assumes Euclidean geometry and does not hold in non-Euclidean spaces where parallel lines may converge or diverge.
In practical applications, Euclidean geometry is overwhelmingly sufficient for calculating areas of rectangles, as non-Euclidean effects are negligible at human scales.
The formula fails for degenerate rectangles where length or width is zero, as the area becomes zero despite the other dimension being non-zero.
Degenerate rectangles are edge cases and not considered valid rectangles in standard geometric definitions, so the formula remains universally correct for non-degenerate cases.

supporting.text: Mathematical textbooks universally define the area of a rectangle as the product of its length and width, confirming this as a fundamental geometric principle.

attacks.text: Mathematical textbooks universally define the area of a rectangle as the product of its length and width, confirming this as a fundamental geometric principle.
The formula assumes Euclidean geometry and does not hold in non-Euclidean spaces where parallel lines may converge or diverge.
For practical applications, Euclidean geometry is overwhelmingly sufficient, and non-Euclidean cases are rare exceptions in everyday contexts.
The formula fails for degenerate rectangles (e.g., zero length or width), where the area is zero but the product definition may not be meaningful.
Degenerate cases are trivial exceptions and do not invalidate the general formula, which is defined for positive dimensions.

supporting.text: Empirical measurements of rectangular shapes consistently yield areas that match the product of their length and width, validating the formula.

attacks.text: Empirical measurements of rectangular shapes consistently yield areas that match the product of their length and width, validating the formula.
The formula assumes Euclidean geometry and fails in non-Euclidean spaces where parallel lines may not remain equidistant.
In practical applications, nearly all physical rectangles exist in Euclidean space, making non-Euclidean exceptions irrelevant for most use cases.
Measurement errors or physical deformations in real-world rectangles can cause deviations from the idealized formula.
Standard measurement protocols account for error margins, and rigid materials minimize deformation, preserving formula accuracy.

supporting.text: The formula is consistent with dimensional analysis, where multiplying two lengths (in the same units) results in a quantity with units of area (e.g., square meters).

attacks.text: The formula is consistent with dimensional analysis, where multiplying two lengths (in the same units) results in a quantity with units of area (e.g., square meters).
Dimensional analysis alone does not prove the formula's correctness for all geometric cases, such as non-Euclidean spaces where area calculations differ.
In practical applications, Euclidean geometry is the standard framework, and non-Euclidean cases are exceptions that do not invalidate the general formula.
The formula assumes perfect measurement precision, but real-world measurements have tolerances that can affect the calculated area.
Measurement tolerances are accounted for in error analysis and do not change the fundamental mathematical relationship expressed by the formula.

supporting.text: The area formula for a rectangle is a special case of the more general area formula for parallelograms (base × height), where the height equals the width when the angle is 90 degrees.

attacks.text: The area formula for a rectangle is a special case of the more general area formula for parallelograms (base × height), where the height equals the width when the angle is 90 degrees.
The formula for the area of a rectangle is independently derived from the definition of area as the product of its side lengths, not merely as a special case of parallelograms.
The derivation of the area of a rectangle from first principles (counting unit squares) is more fundamental and does not rely on the properties of parallelograms.
The area formula for rectangles predates the general formula for parallelograms historically, showing its independent conceptual origin.
Historical precedence does not necessarily imply logical independence; later generalizations can still subsume earlier special cases.
